subject: Investing
title: Call Risk and Early Redemption
description: A fast breakdown of Call Risk and Early Redemption for builders.

hook.text: You bought a bond paying 7%. Rates drop to 4%. The issuer calls the bond back early. Now you're stuck reinvesting at 4%.

buildup.text: Callable bonds let the issuer repay early, usually when rates fall. It benefits them, not you.

discovery.text: Call protection periods prevent early redemption for a set number of years, giving bondholders some safety.

twist.text: Callable bonds offer slightly higher yields to compensate for call risk. You get paid for the uncertainty.

climax.text: When rates drop sharply, waves of bonds get called. Investors suddenly face reinvestment at much lower yields.

punchline.text: Call risk means the issuer wins when rates fall. You lose your high-yield bond.

quiz.question: When do issuers typically call a bond?
options: When interest rates fall below the bond's coupon rate
